TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals , who were both born in DATE and live in GPE , GPE . They are represented before the ORG by Mr A. GPE , legal adviser of ORG in GPE , and Mr PERSON , barrister and professor of law at ORG . The respondent Government are represented by PERSON , Director of ORG of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

PERSON , the first applicant , was born in GPE . In DATE he moved to GPE together with his parents . In DATE he married Ms PERSON , the second applicant , who had been born in GPE in DATE . Both applicants are of NORP origin .

The applicants have CARDINAL children who all live in GPE . Their daughter PERSON ( born in DATE ) is a stateless person . She has a permanent residence permit in GPE . The applicants’ first son PERSON ( born in DATE ) is a NORP national . He too holds a permanent residence permit . The applicants’ second son PERSON ( born in DATE ) is a NORP national and he holds a temporary residence permit in GPE for DATE ( until DATE ) . At the time the application was lodged with the ORG , he was living together with the applicants .

The first applicant ’s mother who had had a permanent residence permit to live in GPE died on DATE . His father ( born in DATE ) , a NORP national , resides in GPE on the basis of a permanent residence permit . The second applicant ’s mother and the applicants’ grandchildren are also living in GPE .
DATE first applicant served in the NORP and NORP armed forces .
On DATE GPE and GPE concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of NORP troops from NORP territory .

In DATE until his assignment to reserve on DATE ( see below ) the first applicant served as a senior midshipman in the LOC military unit . His duties included the dismantling of a nuclear reactor in GPE .

On DATE the commander of the Paldiski military unit issued a decree by which the first applicant was assigned to the reserve as of CARDINAL DATE . He was discharged from the GPE military unit and sent to the LOC military unit in GPE , GPE . According to the decree , it was decided to allocate financial means to the applicants and their CARDINAL sons for their travel to GPE .

As the applicants did not have housing in GPE , the first applicant applied for a flat in GPE within the framework of an aid programme provided by GPE . On DATE he signed a written commitment in this connection . The form of the commitment was in NORP . In the form , signed by the first applicant , it was stated that he wished to take part in the programme for providing housing for officers of the NORP armed forces . It was further stated that if he received housing in the context of the programme , he and his family would vacate the dwelling that was at their disposal in the NORP country and that in the future he would be able to visit the NORP countries only as a foreigner on general basis . Furthermore , it was stated that the applicant had no housing in GPE , that he had not paid anyone for the right to take part in the programme and that he was aware that the housing in the context of the programme would be provided free of charge . It was confirmed that the dwelling he possessed in the NORP country had not been privatised or sold and that he had not received any payment for it .

On DATE the first applicant submitted an application for taking part in the programme . In the application form , signed by the first applicant , it was stated that if he were to receive a dwelling in the context of the aid programme , he , together with his family , would vacate the dwelling that was at his family ’s disposal in the NORP country and not seek to stay in the NORP countries as permanent residents . It further stated that in the future he would be able to visit the NORP countries only as a foreigner . It was stated that he and his family did not possess a dwelling in the NORP countries and that they would not seek to privatise or sell the dwelling at their disposal and that they had not received and would not receive any payment for vacating their current dwelling . It was also stated that he confirmed that at the moment of signing the application he did not have housing in GPE and that he had not paid anyone for the right to take part in the programme . It was stated that he was aware that if all the preconditions for taking part in the programme were fulfilled and he were to comply with all the conditions and requirements of the programme , he would receive money for buying a dwelling . Finally , it was stated that he was also aware that the participation in the programme was voluntary and that if it were to prove unsuccessful , his place in a municipal waiting list of applicants for dwelling would be retained .

On DATE the first applicant concluded an agreement in GPE with the company ORG to the effect that he would pay an equivalent of MONEY and receive an apartment at FAC CARDINAL - CARDINAL in GPE . The agreement was to become valid if the first applicant were to get money in the context of the programme for granting military reserve officers certificates for obtaining housing .
On DATE the applicants submitted an application for a residence permit in GPE .
On DATE the mayor of GPE allocated apartment no . CARDINAL at CARDINAL FAC to the first applicant and ordered that he be registered as its owner .
On DATE , the first applicant was entered in the list of staff of the military unit in GPE .
On DATE the applicants were granted temporary residence permits in GPE for DATE .
As from DATE the first applicant was working as a guard in GPE . The second applicant was working as a housemaid , also in that country , as from DATE .

In DATE LAW ( PERSON seadus ) was amended so as to exclude the possibility of issuing or extending residence permits to persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE or who had received an accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme .

On DATE the second applicant privatised ( purchased on favourable conditions from the municipality ) an apartment no . CARDINAL at CARDINAL FAC in GPE . On DATE the second applicant , acting as her son PERSON ’s proxy , privatised an apartment no . CARDINAL at CARDINAL Kivi Street in GPE .

On DATE the applicants applied for extensions of their residence permits . On DATE the Minister of the ORG issued orders by which the applicants were refused extensions . The refusal was based on CARDINAL grounds . Firstly , the first applicant had served as a professional member of the armed forces of a foreign country and had retired . This ground applied also to the second applicant as a family member of the first applicant . Secondly , the applicants had committed themselves to leaving GPE and had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme .

The applicants submitted a complaint to ORG ( PERSON NORP ) . They contested the retroactive application of the provisions of LAW so as to refuse extensions of residence permits of persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE and who had received an accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . LAW did not contain the disputed provisions at the time when the applicants participated in the aid programme and received accommodation in GPE . They argued that their legitimate expectation rights and the principle of legal certainty had been violated . They also maintained that their commitment to leave the country had not been made to the NORP authorities . They further complained that their right to family and private life had been violated .

On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint . It observed that LAW provided that the residence permits of former professional members of armed forces of a foreign country and of their family members could be extended only in exceptional circumstances . Although the Minister of the ORG ’s orders did not state why such an exception did not apply in the applicants’ case , ORG found the orders to be lawful , since LAW in any case did not permit extensions of residence permits of persons who had committed themselves to leaving GPE and who had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . It dismissed the applicants’ claim that their legitimate expectation rights and the principle of legal certainty had been violated , holding that the principle of legitimate expectation could not be extended so far as to prevent the legislator from making any changes to the legislation in force at any point of time . ORG rejected the complaint concerning the violation of the right to family and private life , finding that the applicants could enjoy family life in the country of which they were nationals and in which they had undertaken to settle , when consenting to participate in the aid programme .

In an appeal to ORG ( Tallinna GPE ) the applicants stressed that the first applicant ’s elderly parents , whom the applicants had to take care of , lived in GPE . The second applicant had been born in GPE and had been living there ever since . The first applicant had lived in GPE for DATE . They supported financially their children , who lived in GPE , including CARDINAL child who lived together with them . Also their grandchildren lived in GPE . The first applicant had opted for the aid programme and adopted NORP nationality only because of the lack of certainty as to the possibility to remain living in GPE .

On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of ORG . ORG noted that in his written consent to take part in the aid programme , the first applicant had stated that the size of his family was CARDINAL persons , including the CARDINAL sons . Thus , the first applicant had known already at the time he had been consenting to take part in the aid programme that his parents would remain in GPE .

On DATE ORG ( NORP ) upheld the judgments . It reiterated that on DATE GPE and GPE had concluded a treaty concerning the withdrawal of the NORP troops from GPE . According to the treaty the NORP military servicemen and their family members had to leave GPE . GPE aid programme had been set up to facilitate the resettling of the military servicemen . The fact that GPE had not been a party to the programme , did not , in ORG view , exclude the legitimacy of the enactment and application of the provision of LAW , under which the applicants had been denied the extensions of the residence permits . ORG agreed with the opinion of ORG that in case the first applicant ’s parents wished to stay in GPE , the grown - up children of the applicants could take care of them .

On DATE ORG ( Kodakondsus- ja GPE ) issued a precept to the applicants requiring them to leave GPE . The applicants complied with the precept and cancelled their registration of residency in GPE . According to the population registration database the applicants left GPE on DATE and settled in GPE . In the applicants’ submission they had to leave GPE in DATE , after the police had entered their flat in DATE in order to execute the precepts by force .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW ( PERSON seadus ) listed the instances in which a residence permit could not be issued or extended . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) provided that a permit could not be issued or extended , if the foreigner applying for it had served as a professional member of the armed forces of a foreign state or had been assigned to the reserve forces thereof or had retired therefrom . DATE ) provided that a residence permit could also not be issued or extended for the spouse and minor children of a person referred to in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) . LAW ) , however , provided that , as an exception , a temporary residence permit could be issued or extended for the foreigner concerned if this was not excluded on some other grounds listed in the same provision .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of the Foreigners’ Act provided that a residence permit could not in any case be issued or extended , if the person concerned had , inter alia , committed himself or herself to leaving GPE or had received accommodation abroad within the framework of an international aid programme . This provision was adopted on DATE and entered into force on DATE . It was subject to an amendment in DATE , which does not appear to have relevance to the present case .

According to the Government of GPE , in DATE the President of GPE and the President of the GPE agreed to undertake a project for providing CARDINAL units of housing for NORP military officers demobilized from the NORP countries or elsewhere outside GPE .

The Government submitted to the ORG a copy of “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program . ORG ” and “ NORP Military Officer Resettlement Program . ORG . ORG ” . These information materials appear to have been handed out by the NORP side in ORG to the participating NORP officers .

According to the information materials , the NORP Military Officer Resettlement Programme had been set up in order to provide CARDINAL units of housing for NORP military officers demobilised mainly from the NORP countries . CARDINAL of the units of housing had to be constructed , whereas the rest of the housing units had to be provided through a housing certificate programme .

In order to take part in the ORG , the officers had to present a discharge order , passport , official verification of the family size and composition , official verification of current residence in the LOC and a signed application for participation in the programme containing declarations that upon obtaining housing under this programme , the officer and his family would vacate their present dwelling(s ) in the LOC countries and would not seek permanent residency in any of ORG , and from then on would enter ORG only as foreign guests . The officers had to declare that they and their families did not own housing in GPE nor would they own , privatise or sell any dwellings in the LOC and would not receive any payments in connection with vacating any dwelling . The officers declared their understanding that if they were found to be eligible to participate in the ORG and if all ORG ’s terms and conditions were met , they would receive appropriate apartments ( in the framework of the housing construction programme ) or financial assistance for the purchase of housing units ( in the framework of the housing certificate programme ) .

In order to obtain a registration of residence ( propiska ) in the Passport Desk for their new apartment , the officers had to present their NORP Passport and the NORP passports for all family members along with proof of cancellation of their registration of residency ( vypiska ) for all members of the family in the LOC . Officers had to move in DATE after notification by ORG or by the local administration , otherwise their apartments could be reassigned .
Participation in the ORG was voluntary ; no enrolment fee was required .

After the independence of GPE was restored on DATE , the NORP troops remained in the country . Following the dissolution of GPE , GPE assumed jurisdiction over its armed forces . On DATE GPE and GPE concluded a treaty on the withdrawal of the NORP troops from the NORP territory and on the conditions of their temporary stay in GPE . On DATE , GPE and GPE concluded an agreement concerning the social guarantees to the retired military personnel of the armed forces of GPE on the territory of GPE . LAW and the LAW entered into force on DATE , having been subject to temporary application from DATE of signing , that is , from DATE .

According to the LAW , ORG undertook to withdraw from GPE , by DATE , all military personnel who were in the active service of the NORP armed forces . Family members of the military personnel in active service who did not have a dwelling in GPE were allowed to remain in GPE for DATE .

The Agreement provided that retired military personnel , i.e. persons discharged from the army service and receiving pension , and their family members could apply for residence permit in GPE . ORG could deny a residence permit due to a threat to national security .

On DATE an agreement on the procedure and terms for the dismantling of the nuclear reactors , and for ensuring nuclear and radiation safety on the Pakri peninsula of GPE was concluded between the Government of GPE and the Government of GPE . This Agreement entered into force on DATE of its signing and it remained effective until DATE . According to the Agreement , work for the dismantling of nuclear reactors and ensuring nuclear and radiation safety was to be performed by specialists of GPE . GPE undertook to give temporary residence permits to the specialists and their family members for the period of validity of the agreement . In cases where the postponement of the departure was required , including the absence of the housing in GPE , the validity of the residence permits of the family members could be extended until DATE . After the expiry of the residence permits the specialists together with their family members had to leave GPE .
